accused.name: Françoise femme Bastien Bourguignon, dite la Vilaume

confession.devil_appearance: soft as a cat, appeared in form of cat
confession.seduction_date: 14 years earlier, in year of first husband's death
confession.seduction_context: Angry because first husband had been fined over carpentry he had done. Persy appeared to her while she was sleeping in 'chambre a fourq' because of ill treatment by her husband
powder_types: powder given by Persy (thrown away initially, later admitted using to kill child and attempting to poison husband)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Agreed to bring logs back for accused but his men found them too large and difficult and did not do so

harms_alleged.target: several other animals including cows, pigs, and horses

testimony.quarrel_subject: Same story as husband about logs - logs were 'pleine d'espines' (full of thorns)
Accused made comments about his 6-month-old son saying he was making too much of the child since it was a boy and they already had one and would have more children

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 2 or 3 days later fell ill, died 2 weeks later

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her husband enforced payment by accused's first husband Jean Wilaume for grain he owed them; accused addressed herself to them very angrily

witnesses.name: Marguerite Jeune fille Claudon Martin dit Cordonnier
witnesses.occupation: servant in house of sieur Blanche Charrier

witnesses.name: Catherine femme Nicolas Symmonet dit Pacquatte

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness was frightened of smallpox and asked accused not to bring her sick children to poisle where they both went, but accused replied they would go and wouldn't do anything for anyone

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 2 days later sickened, died 3 days later
immediately after she came to house

testimony.quarrel_subject: Husband sold 'huys' to accused but had lost key; accused made repeated angry visits asking for it

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: soon after accused commented baby's cries were weak, child died in 3 days

testimony.quarrel_subject: In 1601 had to collect debt of 18 francs owed by her first husband; quarrel when he tried to sell property and she then offered money. He called her 'cocquine', she said his wife was one too, and he struck her saying his wife was not reputed a witch
Accused called to help with sheepshearing but damaged all animals she handled; witness told her to go away unless she could do better job, at which accused left indignantly

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Confronted with Colatte veuve Cezar Laurette, who maintained her charges that she had seen her at sabat

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Second confrontation with Colatte as latter was attached to stake ready for execution; she maintained her charges before large number of people

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Order from substitut of PG de Lorraine for her arrest, following accusation by Colatte and in view of general reputation

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; no reproaches, denied all charges

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: PG (C.M. Rémy) asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; confessed to witchcraft, named accomplices

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Confirmed earlier confessions and accusations; confronted with two women she had accused, maintained charges

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves, adding that she should be strangled

timeline.subject: Françoise Bourguignon
timeline.details: Final death sentence from court at Amance

accomplices_named.name: Jacquotte femme Nicolas Tixerand
accomplices_named.context: Named during torture interrogation on 25 January 1616

accomplices_named.name: veuve Mariatte
accomplices_named.context: Named during torture interrogation on 25 January 1616; confronted on 26 January, went down on her knees begging accused to retract but accused maintained charges

prior_accusations.context: Accused her of being at sabat; maintained charges twice including at stake before execution
Executed at Neufchâteau, had accused her; accused believed this followed occasion when he put a dead skull outside their house

prior_accusations.accuser_name: man and woman accused at Neufchâteau
prior_accusations.context: Husband discovered she had been accused by these individuals; checked with Sr de Bernecourt of Change de Nancy who had possession of papers

notable_quotes.speaker: Françoise Bourguignon
notable_quotes.french: qu'il en faisoit des minnes et d'estat, d'aultant que c'estoit un garçon et qu'ilz en avoient desja un et qu'ilz auroient encore assez d'enfants, et ne falloit tant faire d'estat des premiers
notable_quotes.context: Comment made to Jean Charton about his 6-month-old son before touching child's clothes; child died 2 weeks later

notable_quotes.speaker: Hublotte veuve Nicolas Piers
notable_quotes.french: et qu'elle luy sembloit telle, de cause qu'à tous propos, en jurantz et maulgreans, elle donnoit son ame au diable
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why accused had reputation as witch - she constantly gave her soul to the devil in her speech

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon femme Clement d'Agincourt
notable_quotes.french: que le plus souvent quand elle veut affirmer quelque chose, et quasy de tous propos, elle donne son ame au diable, et qu'elle luy a ouy dire en plusieurs fois, que sy elle estoit sorciere, elle feroit merveilles, et feroit mourir son marit
notable_quotes.context: Testimony about accused's habitual speech patterns and threats against husband

notable_quotes.speaker: Françoise Bourguignon
notable_quotes.context: Response when advised to have patience

notable_quotes.speaker: Françoise Bourguignon
notable_quotes.french: qu'ils y iroient et n'en feroient rien pour personne
notable_quotes.context: Defiant response when asked not to bring sick children to poisle during smallpox outbreak

notable_quotes.speaker: Gerard Marchal's valets
notable_quotes.french: des bougres et des diables de fagots
notable_quotes.context: Comments about the logs they were supposed to cart for accused

notable_quotes.speaker: Françoise Bourguignon
notable_quotes.french: a cause que ledit Charton le tenant entre ses bras et faisoit trop de mines de luy
notable_quotes.context: Confession under torture explaining why she killed Jean Charton's child

notable_quotes.speaker: Françoise Bourguignon
notable_quotes.french: elle avoit trop besoin des biens de la terre
notable_quotes.context: Explanation under torture for why she had not caused hailstorms

relationships.evidence_text: Marguerite Jeune, fille Claudon Martin dit Cordonnier
Was servant in house of sieur Blanche Charrier
Catherine femme Nicolas Symmonet, dit Pacquatte, vigneron

economic_context.details: Multiple debt-related conflicts: (1) Witness 5 - her first husband enforced payment for grain owed by accused's first husband Jean Wilaume, 15-16 years earlier, leading to angry exchange and subsequent death of 4 horses; (2) Witness 22 - in 1601 had to collect debt of 18 francs owed by first husband, quarrel when trying to sell property, his daughter became sick 2 weeks later; (3) Witness 1 - dispute over carting logs; (4) Witness 19 - dispute over lost key for 'huys' sold to accused

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Agreed to bring logs back but men found them too large and difficult, did not do so, she was very angry
Accused made comments about the child being a boy and witness making too much of him

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: Marie veuve Claudin Vosgien and her late husband's horses
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Husband enforced payment for grain owed by accused's first husband, she addressed herself to them very angrily

harms_catalog.harm_description: sickened (not obviously with smallpox), died 3 days later
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Asked accused not to bring sick children to poisle during smallpox outbreak, accused refused defiantly

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell down and hurt forehead while carrying water (pitcher unharmed)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to let accused have white bread on credit
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: saw her in street soon after
immediately after she came to house

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Husband sold 'huys' to accused but lost key; accused made repeated angry visits asking for it
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: soon after accused said baby's cries were weak

harms_catalog.harm_description: milk turned, stomach injury as if butted but herdsman saw nothing
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Complained about milk turning, accused asked to have some but witness did not give any

harms_catalog.harm_description: became sick, bedridden for 4 or 5 years until she died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Collecting debt of 18 francs from first husband, called her 'cocquine', she said his wife was one too, he struck her

harms_catalog.harm_description: very ill with stomach pains (recovered next day)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Accused damaged sheep during shearing, witness told her to go away unless she could do better, accused left indignantly

material_culture.context: Gerard Marchal agreed to cart logs for accused but men found them too large and difficult; logs described as 'pleine d'espines' (full of thorns)
Toussaint put a dead skull outside accused's house; husband took it to cemetery of Amance
Debt for grain owed by accused's first husband to Marie veuve Claudin Vosgien and her husband
Catherine femme Nicolas Symmonet was selling white bread, refused to let accused have some on credit
Catherine was carrying water pitcher when she fell and hurt forehead, but pitcher was unharmed
Barbillon's husband sold 'huys' to accused but had lost the key
Money given to accused by Persy which turned out to be oak leaves
Given to accused by Persy; claimed to have thrown away initially, later admitted using to kill child and attempt to poison husband
Accused admitted trying to poison husband twice by putting powder in soup, but he detected bitter taste
Neighbors sprinkled holy water on body of dead child; accused suspected because she never came to do so

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused
Court location; cemetery where husband took skull
Location where Toussaint and other accusers were executed; where accused had been previously accused
Location of Change de Nancy (appeals court)
Location where witness Anthoine Cherier served as sergent de justice
Where Colin Aubert was receveur; where accused helped with sheepshearing
Where accused was sleeping when devil first appeared to her; sleeping there because of ill treatment by husband
Community space where Catherine and accused both went; site of dispute over bringing sick children during smallpox outbreak
Accused confessed to attending sabat twice; dancing occurred there
Where accused was caught in time of first husband, taken to court by wife of Sr Faleze
Where horse worth 30 écus died at Nicolas Jacquart's father's house

economic_hardship_indicators: Request for credit for white bread refused
Carpentry work done by first husband resulted in fine
religious_calendar_references: Brandons (festival time when Barbillon gave birth)

prior_legal_disputes.description: In time of first husband Jean Vilaume, taken to court by wife of Sr Faleze after being caught in his vines; denied taking grapes as they had been harvested

legal_context.redress_outcome: Could not get reparation when Gerard Marchal's wife accused her of witchcraft because there were no witnesses

hearsay_chains.content: Woman treating him in his house had twice said the accused was a witch
Had heard husband say he would have her burned, and calling her witch
Had only heard her being accused as witch by her husband
Had heard her called witch by husband

emotional_state_notes: Made great complaints after being beaten by husband but produced no tears (witness 11)
Left indignantly when told to go away from sheepshearing (witness 23)
Very angry when men did not cart logs (witness 1)
Addressed herself very angrily about debt payment (witness 5)
Made repeated visits asking angrily for lost key (witness 19)

third_parties.name: Colatte veuve Cezar Laurette
third_parties.context: Accused Françoise of being at sabat; maintained charges twice including at stake before execution on 2 January 1616; called 'la grosse Collotte'

third_parties.name: Toussaint
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: antagonistic - put dead skull outside house
third_parties.context: Executed at Neufchâteau; had accused Françoise; had put dead skull outside their house

third_parties.name: Sr de Bernecourt
third_parties.context: Member of Change de Nancy who had possession of papers regarding accusations at Neufchâteau

third_parties.name: Jean Vilaume
third_parties.context: Accused's first husband; died 14 years before trial; had been fined for carpentry work; owed debts for grain

third_parties.name: Sr Faleze
third_parties.context: Wife took accused to court for being caught in his vines

third_parties.name: wife of Sr Faleze
third_parties.context: Took accused to court after she was caught in vines

third_parties.name: Colas Vosgien
third_parties.context: Dispute about payment of debts 15-16 years earlier; referred to as 'late'

third_parties.name: Nicolas Jacquart's mother
third_parties.context: Called accused to house after horse died and accused her of being witch and killing horse

third_parties.name: sieur Blanche Charrier
third_parties.context: Marguerite Jeune was servant in his house

third_parties.name: Claudin Thierion
third_parties.context: Sold 'huys' to accused but lost key

third_parties.name: Colin Aubert
third_parties.context: Husband of witness 23; was receveur at Lay-sous-Amance where accused helped with sheepshearing

third_parties.name: veuve Mariatte
third_parties.context: Named as accomplice during torture; confronted and went on knees begging for retraction but accused maintained charges

third_parties.name: man and woman at Neufchâteau
third_parties.context: Had accused Françoise; husband discovered this and checked with Change de Nancy

third_parties.name: Persy
third_parties.context: Devil who seduced accused; appeared as cat, gave her money (oak leaves) and powder, had sexual relations with her

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete extraction from 5-page English translation of trial record. Trial shows pattern of reputation evidence, multiple quarrel-harm sequences, marital conflict (husband suspected and beat her), prior accusations from executed witches, confession under torture with devil pact narrative, and naming of accomplices. Notable elements include accused's habitual speech pattern of giving soul to devil, husband's suspicion and surveillance, economic disputes (debts, property), and detailed harm catalog spanning human deaths (especially children), animal deaths, and illnesses. Torture progression from thumbscrews to rack produced increasingly detailed confession. Death sentence approved by Change de Nancy with addition of strangling.
